recordings.rmk: First two shiny days after winter, male still in the winter flock, developing the song from contact calls on the beginning, through halftone to nearly (but not full) full tone, on the top of Popula tree with 3 other birds, while rest of the flock (31 birds) feeding on the seeds of Chenopodium sp.
Wintering folck

Lonely male
Some kind "fighting on songs" by male to second male in presence of own female by the nesting place
Male to second male in presence of own female by the nesting place.
Short type of song and long in the presence of female

Male after loosing the female hunted on the nest by domestic cat.
Two delays cutted off.

Song from juvenil male

recordings.type: autumn song of an old male (at leas second calendar year) and a female/juvenile
recordings.rmk: Two linnets in a garden in a residential area. One old male (age confirmed by molt pattern) "singing" quietly, then the female/juvenile bird starts to "sing" as well. These are not the typical full territorial songs, but very quiet and with a lot of time between the individual notes.

A flock of 3 Linnets (all 3 visually confirmed) flying past, one of them calling differently to the others. It could be seen that one of the three had shorter flight feathers than the others, so I conclude that this was a juvenile, old enougth to fly, but with plumage not fully grown yet. They landed in a bush some distance away, but close enougth to keep on recording.

recordings.loc: campos de hernán perea, sierra de segura, jaén, andalucía
recordings.file-name: XC372934-linaria cannabina 2 campos de hern+ín perea 13-04-2017.mp3
recordings.rmk: Al principio de la canción emite notas prolongadas de exibición. Tarde con mucho viento en un manantial natural que suministra agua a un abrevadero de ganado. El chorro de agua que surge de la piedra ha labrado un cuenco natural donde beben y se bañan diversas especies de aves. La vegetación circundante consiste en un tupido bosque de chopos, pinos y también pinsapos y cedros, estas dos últimas especies traídas por el icona.

recordings.loc: Kuplonga, Kilemarskiy rayon, Respublika Mariy El

recordings.rmk: Songscape de pardillo. Este lugar es un rico mosaico de ecosistemas cuyo cordón umbilical es un cauce de arroyo ahora seco por la falta de lluvias que hemos tenido este otoño. Hay alguna alameda con árboles de sorprendente tamaño, carrizal y tarajal, pero la mayor parte de la vegetación de las orillas ha desaparecido por la acción de los agricultores. Más allá hay una serie de eriales, viñedos, cercados de ganado, pinares, y restos de bosques de quercíneas. Las grabaciones han sido realizadas en un pequeño cauce afluente del arroyo principal que debe tener un manantial por lo cual es el único lugar que ofrece agua disponible en una gran distancia. Por este motivo hay allí montones de pajarillos que por la tarde se congregan para bañarse y beber. Otro motivo es que la vegetación riparia formada por un denso zarzal y zonas de carrizo se ha respetado.
Song from a reed in an open field close to the water.
Migrating.

recordings.type: Flight call and fragment of song of a flock in flight., flight call

recordings.loc: cerca del pantano de la minilla, sevilla, andalucía
recordings.file-name: XC278438-linaria cannabina pantano de la minilla 27-05-2015.mp3
recordings.rmk: El hábitat consiste en bosque mediterráneo de quercíneas y acebuches mezclado con matorral. El suelo es más bien escarpado y hay algunos valles en los que se acumula más la humedad y son de carácter más humbrío. También hay algunos cultivos y la zona está salpicada de construcciones destinadas al ganado, como almacenes, cercados, etc.
high pass filter

The clip opens with a burst of twitters from several Linnets that were feeding on broadcast seed and the ripening heads of dandelions. Twittering calls typically accompany take-offs and are also characteristic of flying birds. The same twitters can be heard a few times over the course of the recording, such as at 0:15. Linnets utter a variety of other  discordant notes. These one-off calls can be stretched, as though elastic, and tail off into a kind of echo, such as the 'whee-oo' at 0:03. A different twanging utterance comes at 0:05 and fits the metre of the word 'potpourri'. In the background a Reed Bunting can be heard giving its soft down-slurred pipe, best heard at 0:12, 0:14, 0:17 and 0:19.
Song from the top of a tree in a field. Wind noise has been filtered.
high pass filter,
Family group
Song from a bird in the top of a small spruce in an overgrown field. A lot of other birds in the background. A cold, sunny morning. Traffic noise has been filtered.
30 individuals perched on a tree top

Linnets are social by nature. When a group is encountered at the start of the breeding season there is bound to be a mixture of twittering, song and flight calls (because Linnets are restless by nature and startle easily). Around ten birds were present for this recording and throughout  the first 15 seconds the trademark short twitter is repeated several times. The notes are uniform and 'flat' (they do not rise or fall) and in my mind suggest a squeak that needs oiling. At 0:18 some of the group startle and produce the typical Linnet hubbub of fast twitters, an effect created because several birds call. Not all in the flock flew off and the remainder of the clip features calls that are not connected to any kind of alarm. A standard sound that functions as a kind of 'flag of identification' is the twanging 'coo-ee' note given at 0:23 and 0:29. At no stage was I able to see which individuals made which sound.  From about 40 seconds onwards, two vocalists might have been of the opposite sex. I hope to work this out at a future date. Even if a male and female were involved, I do not know who said what! Nonetheless, a conversation seems to be conducted. At 0:43 a fairly gruff call draws the sweeter 'coo-ee' response at 0:46. Although this is the same note as at 0:23, the utterance comes across as more of a whimper. Perhaps the caller moved to a perch slightly further away or turned its head, thereby reducing the volume and impact of the call. The same two birds continue the same exchange at 0:49 (reply at 0:51), 0:52 (reply at 0:55) and 1:00 (reply at 1:01). Skylark song can be heard throughout the recording. At 0:16 a Skylark flies overhead and utters (fairly faint) a typically burry flight call. Several examples of a high-pitched, almost ultra-sonic, whine occur through the recording, such as at 0:16 (just before Skylark flight call). I assume the sound is made by a Robin. A Meadow Pipit begins its descending song flight at 0:59 and the repeated 'sip, sip, sip' syllables can be heard, albeit not very clearly, right to the end of the clip.

Linnets are social by nature. When a group is encountered at the start of the breeding season there is bound to be a mixture of twittering, song and flight calls (because Linnets are restless by nature and startle easily). Around ten birds were present for this recording and throughout  the first 15 seconds the trademark short twitter is repeated several times. The notes are uniform and 'flat' (they do not rise or fall) and in my mind suggest a squeak that needs oiling. At 0:18 some of the group startle and produce the typical Linnet hubbub of fast twitters from more than one caller. Because some birds did not fly off, the remainder of the clip features calls that are not connected to any kind of alarm. A standard sound by the species as a kind of 'flag of identification' is the twanging note given at 0:24 and 0:29. At no stage was I able to see which individuals made which sound.  From about 40 seconds onwards, two vocalists might have been of the opposite sex. I hope to work this out at a future date. Even if a male and female were involved, I do not know who said what! Nonetheless, a conversation seems to be conducted. At 0:43 a fairly gruff call draws a much sweeter 'coo-ee' response at 0:46. The same two birds continue prolong the same exchange at 0:49 (reply at 0:52), 0:53 (reply at 0:55) and 1:00 (reply at 1:01). Skylark song can be heard throughout the recording. At 0:17 a Skylark flies overhead and utters the a burry flight call.
Small group in low flight over vineyard. Noon.

Quiet song from one of two birds in reed in a ditch close to an open field. The birds were clearly visible in close range. None had any red color. Light rain, no wind. Traffic and aircraft noise has been filtered.

recordings.rmk: Sound trapped in a swamp at the rim of a raised bog, with some open water and some shrubs and trees. The pause between the two parts is 10 min.
Sound trapped in a bog with reeds, ditches and some shrubs.
A group of ca. 6 birds sitting and moving in an oak tree, surrounded by farming and industrial land. Parts omitted because of traffic or wind noise.
Male calling near nest
Mainly calls from juvenile birds also parents around calling back. Towards end a single "burst" from a garden warbler (Sylvia borin)
4 Birds sitting in top of a young pine tree, approximately 3,5m high, calling, then flying away. Birds not aware of recordist. Recording equipment: Telinga Pro 7 Stereo Dat mic, Sound Devices 702.
Part 1 of 2. Family with three juveniles. (Begging) calls of juveniles, various calls of adults and fligh calls. In this cut mainly the juveniles. [52.071, 4.451]
at the border between fen and peat bog with some shrubs
Calls, or snatches of song perhaps...
in a degenerated bog with many shrubs, reeds and pastures; calls change to a kind of song
Migrating birds. Filtered and amplified. [52.130, 4.309]
Somewhat awkward call.
in degenerated bog with ponds, shrubs and trees
